 Consider for a moment what you actually mean by 'materialistically': what is it that defines something as being material? Gravity is every bit as intangible as a miracle, yet you would automatically characterise it as being part of the material world. Why? The answer is that it is amenable to the scientific method: assertions about gravity can be repeatably tested. If ghosts and poltergeists were amenable to the same methodology, it would be possible to construct scientific theories concerning those, too, and they would be considered no more exotic or 'supernatural' than clouds or rainbows.
 
 When you get your head around that, it's immediately apparent that it isn't the power of prayer or spirituality per se that aren't scientific, it's the methodology people have for dealing with them. Indeed, when the scientific method is applied and doesn't yield the results believers in such matters want, the typical response is to come up with excuses why we shouldn't expect the scientific method to work. Unfortunately you can't have it both ways; if you want to come to the party you have to adopt the dress code.

 Nope, I think what's being said is that it was a coincidence. Lots of babies have fevers, lots of parents, in the extremis of worry, pray for them to get better. Usually, they do. Sometimes it happens after lots of prayer, sometimes after just one. Often it happens without any prayer. When prayers don't coincide with recovery people either lose faith or rationalise away the failure of the prayer by saying it wasn't in line with god's plan. When prayers do coincide with recovery, especially very closely, a person's faith can be strongly - if quite accidentally - reinforced.
 
 It's tempting to scoff at 'coincidence' as being a non-explanation, because from an individual perspective it seems like the one life you lead is very unlikely to contain events that are individually very unlikely in themselves. However, with enough people, the odds of something unlikely happening to at least one of them can be very high indeed - hence lotteries have winners despite the odds. The natural response is to say 'yeah, but the odds of that person being me are very low' to which the only answer that matters is "Yes, but the winner could say exactly the same thing." 
 
 Consider for a moment: from your point of view as a conscious individual you experienced miracles, and here you are telling people about them. But from my point of view, you're just the lottery winner. If I wasn't having this conversation with you, I would be having it with the guy who did win, while you mowed the lawn or read a Richard Dawkins book.
 
 The point is not that I disbelieve what happened to you, or think that you should interpret it differently (so long as your beliefs make you happy and don't inspire you or anyone else to take silly risks on the assumption that god will intervene). The point is that that you're conducting false advertising. You're saying that prayer can influence the chances of good things happening to you or someone else, or bad things not happening to you or someone else, and there's no evidence of that whatsoever.
 
 Why isn't your personal experience evidence? I know that probably bugs you most of all, me sitting here smugly discounting what you know to be true. The reason I discount it is that if you were right, and we could alter the chances of events happening through prayer, then we should be able to see that pattern emerge across lots of people, not just individuals. If prayer can help someone recover from illness, then we should logically see those who are prayed for recovering more often and more readily - we don't. How do you explain that? How can prayers heal this individual and that individual, yet make no difference to the proportion who are healed overall?
 
 
Now mind you, I totally reject that, as I know it was God healing my daughter because I know rationally speaking, that I have no supernatural powers within me.

 
 The rational response is to believe your daughter healed herself - that's what her immune system does.
 
 
And I truly understand how difficult it is for someone who has never personally experienced a miracle to not be skeptical about miracles or the supernatural, and maybe if I had experienced only one in my life then I too might question if it really happened.

 
 And I truly understand how difficult it is for someone to whom an powerfully emotionally charged coincidence has occurred to avoid having that colour his worldview to the point where he attributes progressively less remarkable 'miracles' to the same supernatural force. 
 
 So you didn't merely 'not drown', you were supernaturally saved from drowning. Your would-be assailants didn't see something real behind you that was gone when you turned around, they saw a manifestation of your guardian angel invoked by the prayer you uttered as they approached. The fact that you now enter any stressful situation armed with a prayer makes it impossible for you to experience success and not attribute it to the efficacy of your whispered words.
 
 I've had my fair share of close calls too. I've missed seeing a stop sign in the dark (the road ahead banked upward and the sign was above the reach of my headlights) and shot straight across a packed two-lane highway in the middle of rush hour, into - not a brick wall, or even another road, but a gated car park whose entrance just happened to be opposite and whose gate just happened to be raised at the time. Had things been slightly different, I'd be dead now. Miraculous? No. When I said 'fair share', I meant exactly that. The person to whom nothing remotely remarkable happens is himself a statistical phenomenon.
 
 Had you drowned, you would not be here saying it was a miracle - but someone would be, relating a similar story of miraculous survival which your silent voice would be unable to debunk. And if - perish the thought - your daughter had not recovered from her illness, you would not be here describing that miraculous event - but someone would be, telling a similar tale of faith-healing, using their words to convince others of something you in your grief would know was untrue. It just so happens that thanks to the happy accidents that have occurred in your life, you are that someone, while it is left to others to drown alone with their prayers unanswered, or to rationalise away their rage against an indifferent god by their daughter's graveside.

 Cerenkov radiation (also spelled Cerenkov or Cherenkov) is electromagnetic radiation emitted when a charged particle passes through an insulator at a speed greater than the speed of light in that medium.  WIKI has this to say among other things:
 
 
Regeneration occurs in many, if not all vertebrate embryos, and is present in some adult animals such as salamanders ( e.g. [1]). Mammals exhibit limited regenerative abilities, although not as impressive as salamanders. Examples of mammalian regeneration include antlers, finger tips and holes in ears. Finger tip regeneration has been well characterized, and these studies have resulted in the first demonstration of a genetic pathway controlling regeneration in a mammal. Several species of mammals can regenerate ear holes; a phenomenon that has been most studied in the MRL mouse. If the processes behind regeneration are fully understood, it is believed this would lead to better treatment for individuals with nerve injuries (such as those resulting from a broken back or a polio infection), missing limbs, and/or damaged or destroyed organs.
 
 Regeneration of a lost limb occurs in two major steps, first de-differentiation of adult cells into a stem cell state similar to embryonic cells and second, development of these cells into new tissue more or less the same way it developed the first time [7]. Some animals like planarians instead keep clusters of non-differentiated cells within their bodies, which migrate to the parts of the body that need healing. newt and axolotl), hydra, horseshoe crabs and a type of mouse.

 Traits that are advantageous in terms of leading to more offspring get passed on, and those that don't pay for themselves in terms of leading to more offspring are likely to be lost. In the case of regeneration, it would be of obvious benefit to us, but the ability was lost way back in early mammals. I'd speculate (not being an expert on this) that loss of regeneration stems from mammals requiring much more food much more frequently than reptiles and amphibians. First, mammals gave up indeterminate growth in order to enjoy the benefits of speed, hard bony joints, and occluding teeth with respect to getting more food, and that may well have required giving up regeneration. Second, because mammals need so much food, the loss of a leg would likely prove fatal in mammals well before its use was regained, so regeneration need not have been that helpful, and its loss was not selectively important.
 
 Note that evolution does not result in perfection: it results in 'good enough'. Designers, other than incompetent ones and ones without pride, usually strive for better than that, don't they?

 Standard experimental techniques exist to determine the propagation speed of forces. When we apply these techniques to gravity, they all yield propagation speeds too great to measure, substantially faster than light-speed. This is because gravity, in contrast to light, has no detectable aberration or propagation delay for its action, even for cases (such as binary pulsars) where sources of gravity accelerate significantly during the light time from source to target.
 
 Near the end of his career, Lorentz is quoted as having graciously conceded the contest: "My theory can obtain all the same results as special relativity, but perhaps not with a comparable simplicity" (private communication from C.O. Alley). Today, with hindsight, we might make a somewhat different assessment: "Special Relativity can explain all the experimental results in Table H that Lorentzian Relativity can, but perhaps not with a comparable simplicity." Even so, SR cannot explain the faster-than-light propagation of gravity, although LR readily can.
 
 We conclude that the speed of gravity may provide the new insight physics has been awaiting to lead the way to unification of the fundamental forces. As shown in Van Flandern, 1993, pp.80-85 and Van Flandern, 1996, it may also be connected with the explanation of the dark matter problem in cosmology. Moreover, the modest switch from SR to LR may correct the "wrong turn" physics must have made to get into the dilemma presented by quantum mechanics, that there appears to be no "deep reality" to the world around us. Quantum phenomena that violate the locality criterion may now be welcomed into conventional physics.

Speaking of "miracles"
 
 ========================
 
 
 From Space Dust to Spacefarers
 
 By Phil Berardelli
 ScienceNOW Daily News
 14 August 2007
 Dirt that acts like DNA? Using computer simulations, a team of physicists has shown that it's possible for dustlike particles to divide, replicate, and even evolve. The findings hint at one way that life could have gotten started on Earth, and even the incredible although remote possibility that life--and perhaps intelligence--could exist among the interstellar clouds of outer space.
 
 Conventional wisdom says life in the universe requires carbon and liquid water. With these two simple necessities, life has crept into just about every nook and cranny on Earth, from the scalding waters of deep ocean vents to the underside of Antarctica's icy rocks. As a consequence, scientists looking for extraterrestrial life have based all of their searches and instruments on the existence of carbon and--on Mars, for example--on minerals that only could have formed in the presence of water.
 
 Now comes the prospect that life might be able to evolve in an astoundingly simple fashion. Reporting online in today's issue of the New Journal of Physics, a team from Russia, Germany, and Australia details how computer simulations of molecular dynamics can produce conditions under which evolution appears to begin spontaneously. In their simulations, free-floating molecules begin organizing into a helixlike structure resembling DNA, and as time passes, more stable molecular arrangements begin replacing less-stable versions. The process proceeds, the authors say, because an electrical property called polarization tends to organize the particles and reduce chaos, much like tuning a radio to the proper frequency can produce clear audio from the static. The findings are particularly intriguing, they say, because molecular clouds are common across the universe, such as in vast zones of dust among the stars of the Milky Way.
 
 The research is sound and it suggests "a mechanism whereby organic matter could assemble faster than in previous models," says plasma physicist Mark Koepke of West Virginia University in Morgantown. The shorter time could mean a greater probability that conventional life exists elsewhere in the universe, he says.
 
 However, astrobiologist Margaret Turnbull of the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, Maryland, cautions against underestimating the critical role that water plays in life. Water is "so fabulous for life" because it shields organic molecules "from the electrical charges that would normally drive them apart." Although the researchers may indeed have found another medium within which complex molecules can interact in sophisticated ways, Turnbull says, it remains to be seen whether the right conditions exist in space for these structures to become "complex enough to seed life on young planets."

Speed of Gravity - empirically measured.
 
 ====================================
 
 The speed of gravity can be calculated from observations of the orbital decay rate of binary pulsars PSR 1913+16 and PSR B1534+12. The orbits of these pulsars around each other is decaying due to loss of energy in the form of gravitational radiation. The rate of this energy loss ("gravitational damping") can be measured, and since it depends on the speed of gravity, comparing the measured values to theory shows that the speed of gravity is equal to the speed of light to within 1%. [11] (However, it should be noted that measuring the speed of gravity by comparing theoretical results with experimental results will depend on the theory; use of a theory other than that of general relativity could in principle show a different speed, although the existence of gravitational damping at all implies that the speed cannot be infinite.)
 
 In September 2002, Sergei Kopeikin and Edward Fomalont announced that they had made an indirect measurement of the speed of gravity, using their data from VLBI measurement of the retarded position of Jupiter on its orbit during Jupiter's transit across the line-of-sight of the bright radio source quasar QSO J0842+1835. Kopeikin and Fomalont concluded that the speed of gravity is between 0.8 and 1.2 times the speed of light, which would be fully consistent with the theoretical prediction of general relativity that the speed of gravity is exactly the same as the speed of light.
 
 Several physicists, including Clifford M. Will and Steve Carlip, have criticized these claims on the grounds that they have allegedly misinterpreted the results of their measurements. However, Kopeikin and Fomalont continue to vigorously argue their case. (See the citations below for the details of the arguments pro and con.)
 
 It is important to understand that none of the participants in this controversy are claiming that general relativity is "wrong". Rather, the debate concerns whether or not Kopeikin and Fomalont have really provided yet another verification of one of its fundamental predictions.

Peeling you keep refering to a study that say's that prayer doesn't work while ignoring tens of millions of examples through out history that say differently. 

 
 Oh, no, I'm not ignoring them at all. What I'm trying to get you to think about is the fallacy of assuming that because A came before B, A has caused B. Human nature makes us very susceptible to this fallacy, perhaps because a false positive is usually safer than a false negative.
 
 In the tens of millions of examples you cite, A is prayer and B is some positive outcome, such as the recovery from illness of a loved one. Pretty much every time the loved one of a religious person falls ill, a prayer will be said to aid their speedy recovery. And when the sick relative duly recovers, another score is chalked up to the efficacy of prayer, regardless of any more prosaic medical intervention that might have also occurred, and regardless of the human body's own formidable defences. Answer honestly now: would you ever now not attribute the recovery of a loved one, at least in part, to the fact you prayed for them?
 
 The more closely coincidental the prayer and the recovery, the more enthusiastically the story will be broadcast, with the attendant tendency for such stories to become embellished a little in the process.
 
 In each instance, it is possible that the believer's interpretation is correct or incorrect: either the prayer did something, or it did not. After all, not every person prayed for recovers, so we know prayer doesn't always have the desired effect. And we know that even those who are not prayed for recover from illness, so it's also possible for a prayer to have no effect but for the patient to recover anyway.
 
 So how do we determine whether a treatment - be it prayer or chemotherapy - positively influences the chances of recovery? One way is to actually be able to trace a causal chain, to forensically identify the treatment as being the source of the cure. As I'm sure you'll agree, this is impossible with alleged instances of faith healing.
 
 The other way is statistical: take a large sample and measure the recovery rate in the absence of the treatment, and the recovery rate in the presence of it. The first group is the control group. Any individual instances in which the treatment healed a patient who would otherwise not have recovered will accumulate in the second group total, in addition to the unaided recovery rate (minus, of course, any instances where the treatment caused the patient not to recover).
 
 When we perform this analysis with prayer - whenever we perform this analysis with prayer - we get the same results. Recovery rates are slightly influenced if the patients are told they are being prayed for (sometimes positively, sometimes negatively). Recovery rates are not affected at all if the patients are not told they are being prayed for.
 
 In other words, the number of additional instances in which prayer effected a recovery are zero, which means that either every individual instance of prayer had no effect, or that prayer helps and hinders recovery in equal numbers. Since the latter is more unlikely than the former, we are forced to conclude that certainly in the overwhelming majority of cases, and most likely in all cases where prayer comes before a recovery, the two events are causally unconnected.

 I was 17 years old and staying at the Travel Lodge on W-42nd St. in New York City in 1970. That was hooker row and remember, I didn't accept Jesus for another 5 years at 22 yrs old. Maybe 5 or 10 of the people I passed while on that walk actually looked and even saw me. The rest of them were walking right towards me, but strangely, they made very wide archs or loops around me. As if they couldn't walk past me because there was an obstacle on either side of the that prevented them from getting close enough to just walk past me like we all walk past each other every day of our lives on the street.

 
 You know, I once had a slightly similar experience, though without the hookers. The first weekend in March in 1973, my freshman year, a friend and I hitchhiked to Chicago to spend a couple of days visiting the museums and to see a Monet exhibit. We spent the evening walking the streets, mostly around the loop, to kill time and stay warm (because it was beastly cold) and we spent the night sitting/dozing in Union Station and in the Greyhound bus station (too cheap/broke for a hotel, plus we were having a sort of a contest to see who could spend less on a weekend in the big city, excluding museum entrance fees - if I recall, we clocked in a few cents on either side of $2, but I forget which of us won). Chicago had a dangerous reputation back then, so I at least was pretty nervous while walking around. Probably largely because of the cold and the late hour, but entirely in keeping with the area's unsafe reputation back then, the streets were nearly deserted and kind of spooky. I kept furtively looking at the few other people we encountered, all of whom looked suspicious and most of whom seemed to be sizing us up without making eye contact. Just as you experienced, the people seemed to detour around us for some reason. In retrospect, I suppose I should have been aware of the angelic host following me down the street, but at the time it seemed adequately explained when I suddenly realized that these scary people were in fact crossing the street to avoid us. Those scary people (and some of them seemed really scary), in fact, were afraid of us. This was a stunning revelation at the time, as I had never before thought of myself as scary.
